newsitem.title: FINLAND: FINNISH C/A SURPLUS TO GROW, MARKKA TO FIRM - PROTOS.
newsitem.headline: FINNISH C/A SURPLUS TO GROW, MARKKA TO FIRM - PROTOS.

text.p: Finland's trade and current account surpluses are likely grow further in coming years and the markka will be under pressure appreciate, brokerage Davy Protos said in an October 18 report received on Tuesday.
"It should be clear for everybody, that at least the competitiveness of Finnish export companies will be very good for the next 2-3 years," Protos said.

Assuming that USD/DEM will remain above 1.45 over the next two years and that the world economy will avoid recession, "Finland's current account surplus that is currently almost four percent of GDP will widen further," it said.
Finnish exporters stood to gain because the markka was linked to ERM at a level "where it is 10-20 percent undervalued against the trade-weighted index," Protos said.

"The artificially favourable position of Finnish export companies would lead to a 10 percent tradee balance surplus in 1998," Protos said, adding this would push the C/A surplus up to "something like six percent of GDP."
The markka would inevitably strengthen, it said.
"This means that if the markka will be held in a narrow +/-2.25 percent band in ERM, we see a risk of a major correction in 2-3 years time," Protos said.
